texts.title: A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, for the Advancement of their True and Greatest Interest
texts.sourceDesc: Our copytext is the second edition of 1697, which has some stylistic improvements over the first, and incorporates corrections from the original ERRATA sheet. The text is derived from a transcription of the first 1964 edition from EEBO-TCP. Several changes have been made to this source, correcting some errors and bringing the text in line with the 1697 edition.

texts.title: Letters Concerning the Love of God, Between the Author of the Proposal to the Ladies and Mr. John Norris
texts.sourceDesc: The letters between Astell and Norris were first published in 1695. Our copytext is the second edition of 1705, which is, according to its title page, ‘Corrected by the Authors, with some few Things added’. The text is derived from a transcription of the first edition from EEBO-TCP. Several changes have been made to this source, correcting some errors and bringing the text in line with the 1705 edition.

texts.title: Six Familiar Essays
texts.sourceDesc: Astell’s [Six Familiar Essays] were published in 1696. This first and only edition is our copytext. The text here derives from the transcription of the work from EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, Part II
Reflections Upon Marriage
texts.sourceDesc: Astell’s [Reflections Upon Marriage] was first published in 1700. Our copytext is the third edition of 1706, to which ‘A Preface, in Answer to some Objections’ is added. The text of the reflections themselves derives from a transcription of the first edition at EEBO-TCP, which has been modified to bring it in line with the third edition. The preface was transcribed for this project.

An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision
texts.sourceDesc: Berkeley’s [Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision] was first published in 1710, but our copytext is the edition of 1732, included in the second edition of [Alciphron](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/berkeley/a). The text here derives from David Wilkins’s online edition.

texts.title: A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge
texts.sourceDesc: Berkeley’s [Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge] was first published in 1710, and then again in 1734 together with the [Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous]. Our copytext is this later edition, which corrects a few typographical errors, makes some small stylistic improvements, and uses more modern spelling. The original dedication and preface from the 1710 edition, not reprinted in 1734, are also included. The text here derives from David Wilkins’s online edition.

texts.title: Passive Obedience
Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
texts.sourceDesc: Berkeley’s [Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous] was first published in 1713. Our copytext is the third edition of 1734, and the text derives from David Wilkins’s online edition.

Fifteen Sermons Preached at the Rolls Chapel, to which are added Six Sermons Preached on Publick Occasions
texts.sourceDesc: Butler’s [Fifteeen Sermons Preached at the Rolls Chapel] were first published in 1726. A second edition was produced in 1729, which included a new preface. A third edition of 1736 was simply a reprint of the second. A fourth edition of 1749 included six additional sermons preached on various occasions. This final edition is our copytext.

texts.title: The Analogy of Religion
texts.sourceDesc: Butler’s [Analogy of Religion] was first published in 1736. It was so successful that a second (corrected) edition was printed that same year. Our copytext is the third edition of 1740, the last edition to be published in Butler’s lifetime. The text here derives from the transcription of Howard Malcolm’s 1869 edition, available from Project Gutenberg. Malcolm’s edition makes substantial changes to the text, updating it to 19th century style and conventions, but this is the only transcribed version of the text currently available. We are modifying the text to bring it back in line with the original 1740 edition.

texts.title: Philosophical Fancies
The Worlds Olio
The Philosophical and Physical Opinions
Orations of Divers Sorts, Accommodated to Divers Places
Philosophical Letters; Or, Modest Reflections Upon some Opinions in Natural Philosophy
CCXI Sociable Letters
Observations upon Experimental Philosophy
The Description of a New World, called the Blazing World
Grounds of Natural Philosophy
Letters on the Improvement of the Mind
Essays upon Several Subjects, In Prose and Verse
An Examination of the Notion of Moral Good and Evil
texts.sourceDesc: John Clarke’s [Examination of the Notion of Moral Good and Evil] is an attack on William Wollaston’s [Religion of Nature Delineated](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/wollaston/rnd). The text here derives from Stanley Tweyman’s edition of the latter (Delmar, New York: Scholars’ Facsimiles and Reprints), which includes Clarke’s criticism, as well as an anonymous defence of Wollaston written in response to Clarke (also published in 1725; Wollaston himself died in 1724).

texts.title: The Foundation of Morality in Theory and Practice
An Examination of What Has Been Advanced Relating to Moral Obligation
A Demonstration of the Being and Attributes of God
A Discourse on the Unchangeable Obligations of Natural Religion
Letters to Mr Dodwell, with Clarke's Defences and Collin's Answers
texts.sourceDesc: In 1706, Clarke published a [Letter to Mr Dodwell], in response to his [Epistolary Discourse](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/dodwell/ed). Shortly after, Collins published a [Letter to the Learned Mr. Henry Dodwell], as a direct response to Clarke's criticisms. A series of public letters between Clarke and Collins followed over the next few years, furthering the debate. They were never published as a set, but it was thought convenient to reproduce them here in that fashion.

texts.title: The Scripture-Doctrine of the Trinity
Three Letters to Dr Clarke, from a Clergyman of the Church of England; Concerning his Scripture-Doctrine of the Trinity, with the Doctor's Replies

Seventeen Sermons on Several Occasions

Thoughts on Self-Love
Letters to Mr Dodwell, with Clarke's Defences and Collin's Answers
texts.sourceDesc: In 1706, Clarke published a [Letter to Mr Dodwell], in response to his [Epistolary Discourse](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/dodwell/ed). Shortly after, Collins published a [Letter to the Learned Mr. Henry Dodwell], as a direct response to Clarke's criticisms. A series of public letters between Clarke and Collins followed over the next few years, furthering the debate. They were never published as a set, but it was thought convenient to reproduce them here in that fashion.

texts.title: An Essay concerning the Use of Reason
A Discourse of Free-Thinking
A Farther Discourse of Free-Thinking

A Discourse on the Grounds and Reason of the Christian Religion
A Dissertation on Libery and Necessity
The Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy
texts.sourceDesc: Conway’s [Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy] was first published in 1690 in Amsterdam, in a posthumous Latin translation from the original English manuscript. It was then translated from the Latin back into English, and published in 1692 in London. As the original manuscript sadly does not survive, we have no option but to take this third-hand 1692 version as our copytext. Our general principle on this site is to include only works originally published in the author’s own English, but the unusual history of this work seemed to merit making an exception.

texts.title: The True Intellectual System of the Universe

An Essay in Defense of the Female Sex
texts.sourceDesc: Drake’s [Essay in Defense of the Female Sex] was first published in 1696. Our copytext is the fourth edition, the last published in her lifetime. The text here derives from the transcription of the third edition on wikisource.org, which has been modified to match the fourth edition, which we presume to be more authoriative.

texts.title: A Discourse Concerning the Immediate and Necessary Dependence of all Things upon the Deity

A Brief Vindication of the Fundamental Articles of the Christian Faith
The Eternal and Intrinsick Reasons of Good and Evil
Institutes of Moral Philosophy
A Sober Enquiry into the Nature, Measure and Principle of Moral Virtue
The Interest of Reason in Religion
Patriarcha; or the Natural Power of Kings
The Elements of Moral Philosophy
An Essay on Taste
Dissertations on Subjects Relating to the Genius and Evidences of Christianity
An Essay on Genius
The Vanity of Dogmatizing
Lux Orientalis
Scepsis Scientifica
Logou Threskeia
The Way of Happiness
Philosophia Pia
Essays on Several Important Subjects in Philosophy and Religion
Cursory Remarks on an Enquiry into the Expediency and Propriety of Public or Social Worship
Letters and Essays, Moral and Miscellaneous
Appeal to the Men of Great Britain in behalf of Women
Humane Nature; or, the Fundamental Elements of Policie
texts.sourceDesc: [Humane Nature; or, The Fundamental Elements of Policie] was first published in 1650. Our copytext is the posthumous 3rd edition of 1684, which claims, on its title page, to be ‘Augmented and much corrected by the Authors own hand’, and which has been transcribed and made publicly available at EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Corpore Politico; or, The Elements of Law, Moral and Politick
texts.sourceDesc: [De Corpore Politico; or, The Elements of Law, Moral and Politick] was first published in 1650. Our copytext is the posthumous edition of 1652, because we are not aware of any reason doubt the quality of this edition, and a transcription of it is available at EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Cive; Or, Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society
texts.sourceDesc: [De Cive] was first published in Latin in 1642, and then published in English in 1651, as [Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society]. Our copytext is this first English edition. Though the first to be published, it was destined to become the last of a three-part set. Part one, [De Corpore], was published in 1655, followed by part two, [De Homine], in 1658. Both of these were in Latin; Hobbes never published [De Homine] in English, but an English version of [De Corpore] appeared in 1656, as [The Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/hobbes/cor).

texts.title: Leviathan, or The Matter, Forme, & Power of a Common-Wealth Ecclesiastical and Civill
texts.sourceDesc: The text here is from the 1909 Clarendon Press edition (now in the public domain), as put online by the Online Libary of Liberty. That edition follows the original 1651 edition, but with corrections from the printed ERRATA sheet incorporated into the text.

texts.title: Of Libertie and Necessitie
texts.sourceDesc: The text here follows the original edition, as digitized by EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Corpore; Or, Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body
texts.sourceDesc: [De Corpore] was first published in Latin in 1655, and then published in English in 1656, as [The Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body]. Our copytext is this first English edition. As the English title indicates, it was apparently conceived as the first part of a larger work. Part 2, [De Homine], was published in Latin in 1658, but never appeared in English translation (and is therefore not included on this site). Part 3, [De Cive], was in fact the first part Hobbes wrote, and was published in Latin in 1642. It was also the first to appear in translation, published in 1651 as [Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/hobbes/civ).

texts.title: Behemoth; Or, An Epitome of the Civil Wars of England, from 1640 to 1660
texts.sourceDesc: Hobbes's history of the English Civil Wars was first published in 1679. A posthumous edition was printed in 1682, claiming to be derived from the author's own copy, and to be much more accurate. So far as we are aware this claim is to be taken at face value, and consequently this edition has been chosen as our copytext.

texts.title: An Answer to a Book published by Dr. Bramhall
texts.sourceDesc: Hobbes's reply to Bramhall's criticism, in his [The Catching of the Leviathan (1655)](https://englishphilosophy.org/texts/bramhall/cl), was first published posthumously in 1682.

texts.title: A Treatise of Human Nature
texts.sourceDesc: The first two Books of Hume’s [Treatise of Human Nature] were published together in 1739. The third Book, which included an Appendix making some changes to Book 1, was published in 1740. There was only one edition published in Hume’s lifetime, an this edition is therefore our copytext.

texts.title: An Abstract of a Book Lately Published
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s [Abstract] of his own [Treatise] was published in 1740. Our copytext is that sole edition.

texts.title: Essays, Withdrawn and Unpublished
texts.sourceDesc: The first edition of Hume’s [Essays, Moral and Political] contained eight essays that were later withdrawn from the [Essays, Moral, Political, and Literary, Part 1] (as this collection would ultimately be called). These essays are collected together here, alongside the two unpublished essays [Of Suicide] and [Of the Immortality of the Soul]. These latter were printed in 1755, intended for what became the [Four Dissertations] of 1757, but Hume soon regretted the decision and had them removed, writing the essay [Of the Standard of Taste] to fill their place. A few copies of the 1755 print were circulated (against Hume’s wishes), which therefore serves as our copytext. In preparing the critical text here, the copy held in the National Library of Scotland, containing several modifications in Hume’s hand, was consulted.

texts.title: A Letter from a Gentleman to His Friend in Edinburgh
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s [Letter to a Gentleman] was published in 1745. Our copytext is this sole original edition.

texts.title: Essays and Treatises on Several Subjects
texts.sourceDesc: The first more or less complete edition of Hume’s [Essays and Treatises on Several Subjects], his collected philosophical works, was published in 1758, although each of its component works were published separately before then, and an incomplete version (predating the [Four Dissertations]) was published in 1753. Our copytext is the posthumous edition of 1777, which Hume was working on before he died, and which contains many final alterations.

texts.title: The History of England
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s [History of England] was written in three stages, and in reverse chronological order. He began with two volumes on the History of Great Britain (from the Union of the Crowns to the death of James II), published in 1754 and 1757. In 1759 he then published two more volumes, on the House of Tudor. This necessitated changing the title from the [History of Great Britain] to the [History of England], since he now began the story a century and a half before the union. Finally, in 1762, he published two more volumes tracing the country’s history back even further, all the way to the Celtic Britons and the Roman invasion. In 1763, the first complete set was published, but owing to the size of the work – including the now very large index included in the final volume – it had to be chopped up rather awkwardly into 8 volumes rather than 6. The text here follows the posthumous 1778 edition, which Hume was working on before he died. That edition was also (of necessity) printed in 8 volumes, but it is shown here divided into 6 volumes instead (matching the breaks that appeared in the volumes as they were originally published).

texts.title: My Own Life
texts.sourceDesc: Hume’s short autobiographical [My Own Life] was published in 1777, coinciding with the posthumous edition of his [Essays and Treatises]. Our copytext is this first edition.

texts.title: Dialogues concerning Natural Religion
texts.sourceDesc: Hume began work on his [Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion] in the 1750s. Because of the sensitive nature of the text, however, he did not publish it in his lifetime, but left instructions to his nephew to publish it after his death. It was printed in 1779, and this edition is naturally our copytext. Fortunately, however, Hume’s own manuscript for the work survives. This manuscript was consulted in drawing up the critical text provided here.

texts.title: An Inquiry into the Original of Our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue
texts.sourceDesc: Hutcheson’s [Inquiry into the Original of Our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue] was first published in 1725, with a second edition “Corrected and Enlarg'd” in 1726, and a third “Corrected” in 1729. Our copytext is the fourth edition of 1738, likewise “Corrected”, which contains Hutcheson's final modifications and additions. The text was derived from Wolfgang Leidhold's edition (Indianapolis: Liberty Fund, 2004), which follows the second 1726 edition (noting significant variants from other editions), and removes most of the original italics and small capitals. This source text has been substantially altered, reinstating the original formatting and bringing the text in line with the 1738 edition.

texts.title: An Essay on the Nature and Conduct of the Passions and Affections, with Illustrations on the Moral Sense
texts.sourceDesc: Three editions of Hutcheson's [Essay and Illustrations] were published in the author's lifetime. The second (1730) was merely a reprint of the first, but the third (1742) contained some significant revisions. Consequently the third is our copytext. The text was derived from Aaron Garrett's edition (Indianapolis: Liberty Fund, 2002), which follows the first edition (noting significant differences between this and third). This source text has been substantially altered, to bring the text in line with the 1742 edition.

texts.sourceDesc: Locke’s [Essay] was first published in December 1689, but with a publication year of 1690 on the title page. The copytext for this version is the 4th edition of 1700, which is the last edition to be printed in Locke’s lifetime, and contains several changes and additions. The text is derived from a transcription of the first edition from EEBO-TCP. Several changes are being made to this source, to bring the text in line with the 1700 edition.

texts.sourceDesc: In 1705, Mandeville published an allegorical poem called _The Grumbling Hive, or Knaves Turn'd Honest_. In 1714, he published the poem again, together with a preface, _An Enquiry into the Origin of Moral Virtue_, and several _Remarks_ on the poem, all under the title of _The Fable of the Bees_. Our copytext is the 3rd edition of 1724, to which two additional essays were added. The text here derives from F. B. Kaye's edition (Liberty Fund), as published on the Online Library of Liberty.

texts.title: Free Thoughts on Religion, the Church, and National Happiness
The Fable of the Bees, Part II
texts.sourceDesc: This text was imported from F. B. Kaye's edition (Liberty Fund), as published on the Online Library of Liberty.

texts.sourceDesc: In 1690, Norris published his [Christian Blessedness, or, Discourses upon the Beatitudes of Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ], following this up in 1691 with a set of [Practical Discourses upon Several Divine Subjects]. In 1693 the latter was reprinted as “Volume II”, as was another set titled “Volume III”. Thus the original [Discourses on the Beatitudes] retrospectively became Volume I of these [Practical Discourses]. A fourth volume was printed in 1698.

Our copytext is the second edition of 1705, which is, according to its title page, ‘Corrected by the Authors, with some few Things added’. The text is derived from a transcription of the first edition from EEBO-TCP. Several changes have been made to this source, correcting some errors and bringing the text in line with the 1705 edition.

The Religion of Nature Delineated
texts.sourceDesc: The first edition of [The Religion of Nature Delineated] was published in 1722, but was (according to the advertisement to the second 1724  edition) “transcribed for the press hastily”, and contained “many _errata_ and mistakes”. Our copytext is therefore this second edition, the last to be printed in Wollaston’s lifetime. The text here derives from Stanley Tweyman’s edition (Delmar, New York\: Scholars’ Facsimiles and Reprints).
